sen.j: 応神天皇（おうじんてんのう、仲哀天皇9年12月14日 (旧暦)（201年1月5日） - 応神天皇41年2月15日 (旧暦)（310年3月31日））は、第15代の天皇（在位：応神天皇元年1月1日 (旧暦)（270年2月8日） - 同41年2月15日（310年3月31日））。
sen.e: Emperor Ojin (January 5, 201-March 31, 310) was the fifteenth Emperor, who was in the reign from February 8, 270 to March 31, 310.
Emperor Ojin (January 5, 201-March 31, 310) was the fifteenth Emperor, who was in the reign from February 8, 270 to March 31, 310.
Emperor Ojin (January 5, 201-March 31, 310) was the fifteenth Emperor, who was in the reign from February 8, 270 to March 31, 310.

sen.j: 別名、誉田天皇・誉田別尊（ほむたわけのみこと）。
sen.e: Different names include Homuda no Sumeramikoto and Homutawake no mikoto.
Different names include Homuda no Sumeramikoto and Homutawake no mikoto.

sen.j: 諸説
sen.e: Various Theories
Various Theories
Various Theories

sen.j: 実在性が濃厚な最古の大王（天皇）とも言われるが、仁徳天皇の条と記載の重複・混乱が見られることなどから、応神・仁徳同一説などが出されている。
sen.e: He is said to be the oldest okimi (Emperor), actuality of whose existence is high, but, because descriptions about him overlap and are confused with a paragraph on Emperor Nintoku, there are theories presented including one that Ojin and Nintoku are the same person.

He is said to be the oldest okimi (Emperor), actuality of whose existence is high, but, because descriptions about him overlap and are confused with a paragraph on Emperor Nintoku, there are theories presented including one that Ojin and Nintoku are the same person.

sen.j: その年代は、古事記の干支崩年に従えば、4世紀後半となる。
sen.e: According to the Oriental zodiac of the year of the demise described in Kojiki (The Record of Ancient Matters), his era corresponds to the latter half of the fourth century.
sen.cmt: 「その年代」は「彼の年代」と同義と解釈しました。
sen.e: According to the Oriental zodiac of the year of the demise described in Kojiki (The Record of Ancient Matters), his era corresponds to the latter half of the fourth century.
According to the Oriental zodiac of the year of the demise described in Kojiki (The Record of Ancient Matters), his era corresponds to the latter half of the fourth century.

sen.j: 『記・紀』に記された系譜記事からすると、応神は当時の王統の有力者を合成して作られたものと考えるのが妥当であるとする説がある。
sen.e: From articles on genealogy written in "the Kojiki and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)," there is a theory which claims that it is reasonable to think that Ojin was made up by combining influential persons of the time in the royal line.

From articles on genealogy written in "the Kojiki and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)," there is a theory which claims that it is reasonable to think that Ojin was made up by combining influential persons of the time in the royal line.

sen.j: この実在の不確かさもあり、大王の実像をめぐっては諸説が出されてきた。
sen.e: With this uncertainty of his actual existence, there have been proposed many theories regarding real images of the great king.
With this uncertainty of his actual existence, there have been proposed many theories regarding real images of the great king.
With this uncertainty of his actual existence, there have been proposed many theories regarding real images of the great king.

sen.j: 応神の和風諡号である「ホムダ」は飾りの多い8代以前の天皇と著しく違っている事から実在とみなす説、三王朝交代説における征服王朝の創始者とする説、邪馬台国東遷説にまつわり皇室の先祖として祭られている神（宇佐八幡）とする説、河内王朝の始祖と見なす説などである。
sen.e: They include a theory which regards Ojin to be actual because his Japanese-style posthumous name, 'Homuda,' is extremely different from the embellished ones of the Emperors before the eighth, a theory which postulates that he is the founder of the conquering dynasty in the rotation theory of three dynasties, a theory to regard him as the god (Usa Hachiman) enshrined as an ancestor of the Imperial Family in relation to relocation of the Yamatai-Koku Kingdom to the east, a theory to regard him as the founder of the Kawachi dynasty, etc.
sen.cmt: ①「定訳不明」：「三王朝交代説」は「the rotation theory of three dynasties」と仮訳しました。②「定訳不明」：「河内王朝」は「Kawachi dynasty」と仮訳しました。
sen.e: They include a theory which regards Ojin to be actual because his Japanese-style posthumous name, 'Homuda,' is extremely different from the embellished ones of the Emperors before the eighth, a theory which postulates that he is the founder of the conquering dynasty in the rotation theory of three dynasties, a theory to regard him as the god (Usa Hachiman) enshrined as an ancestor of the Imperial Family in relation to relocation of the Yamatai-Koku Kingdom to the east, a theory to regard him as the founder of the Kawachi dynasty, etc.

They include a theory which regards Ojin to be actual because his Japanese-style posthumous name, 'Homuda,' is extremely different from the embellished ones of the Emperors before the eighth, a theory which postulates that he is the founder of the conquering dynasty in the rotation theory of three dynasties, a theory to regard him as the god (Usa Hachiman) enshrined as an ancestor of the Imperial Family in relation to relocation of the Yamatai-Koku Kingdom to the east, a theory to regard him as the founder of the Kawachi dynasty, etc.

sen.j: また、海外史料との相対比較から、『宋書』や『梁書』に見える倭の五王の讃に比定する説（ほかに仁徳や履中を比定する説もある）、「広開土王碑」に見える倭国の朝鮮進出を指揮した可能性も指摘されている。
sen.e: Also, from relative comparisons with historical materials abroad, there is a theory which identifies him with San of the five kings of Wa, who appear in "Sungshu (Book of the Sung dynasty)" and "Book of the Liang dynasty" (in addition, there are theories which identify Nintoku or Richu with San) and a possibility has been pointed out that he might have directed the advancement of Wakoku (Japan) to Korea,which is written in "Gwanggaeto Stele."

Also, from relative comparisons with historical materials abroad, there is a theory which identifies him with San of the five kings of Wa, who appear in "Sungshu (Book of the Sung dynasty)" and "Book of the Liang dynasty" (in addition, there are theories which identify Nintoku or Richu with San) and a possibility has been pointed out that he might have directed the advancement of Wakoku (Japan) to Korea,which is written in "Gwanggaeto Stele."

Also, from relative comparisons with historical materials abroad, there is a theory which identifies him with San of the five kings of Wa, who appear in "Sungshu (Book of the Sung dynasty)" and "Book of the Liang dynasty" (in addition, there are theories which identify Nintoku or Richu with San) and a possibility has been pointed out that he might have directed the advancement of Wakoku (Japan) to Korea,which is written in "Gwanggaeto Stele."

sen.j: 『日本書紀』には、譽田天皇（ほむたのすめらみこと）・一伝に笥飯大神と交換して得た名である譽田別天皇（ほむたわけのすめらみこと）とあり、分注に去来紗別尊（いざさわけのみこと）とある。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," it appears as Homuta no Sumeramikoto or according to Chapter 1, Homutawake no Sumeramikoto obtained by exchanging names with Kehi no Okami and in the note is described as Izasawake no mikoto.
sen.cmt: ①「一伝」とは「第1章」のことと解釈しました。②「読み方不明」：「笥飯大神」は、ウェブ （http://j-myth.info/nihongi2/nihongi10.html） から「けひのおおかみ」と読みました。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," it appears as Homuta no Sumeramikoto or according to Chapter 1, Homutawake no Sumeramikoto obtained by exchanging names with Kehi no Okami and in the note is described as Izasawake no mikoto.

In "Nihonshoki," it appears as Homuta no Sumeramikoto or according to Chapter 1, Homutawake no Sumeramikoto obtained by exchanging names with Kehi no Okami and in the note is described as Izasawake no mikoto.

sen.j: また、母の神功皇后の胎内にあったときから皇位に就く宿命にあったので、胎中天皇（はらのうちにましますすめらみこと）の敬称がある。
sen.e: Also, from the time he was in the womb of his mother, he was destined to accede to the Imperial throne and, thus, he has a title of honor of Emperor Taichu (Emperor residing in the womb).
Also, from the time he was in the womb of his mother, he was destined to accede to the Imperial throne and, thus, he has a title of honor of Emperor Taichu (Emperor residing in the womb).

sen.j: 『古事記』には、品陀和氣命（ほむだわけのみこと）、別名は大鞆和気命（おおともわけのみこと）とある。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," it appears as Homudawake no mikoto, with another name, Otomowake no mikoto.
In "Kojiki," it appears as Homudawake no mikoto, with another name, Otomowake no mikoto.
In "Kojiki," it appears as Homudawake no mikoto, with another name, Otomowake no mikoto.

sen.j: この別名は天皇が生まれた時、その腕の肉が鞆（とも。弓を射る時に左腕に巻きつける道具）のように盛り上がっていた事に由来するという。
sen.e: It is said that this another name derives from the fact that, when he was born, the muscle of his arm was bulging like a Tomo (a tool to be wound around the left arm when shooting an arrow).
It is said that this another name derives from the fact that, when he was born, the muscle of his arm was bulging like a Tomo (a tool to be wound around the left arm when shooting an arrow).

sen.j: 『播磨国風土記』には、品太天皇（ほむだのすめらみこと）と表記。
sen.e: In "Harimanokuni Fudoki" (Records of the culture and geography of the Harima Province), it is written as Homuda no Sumeramikoto.

sen.j: 「上宮記」逸文には、凡牟都和希王（ほむたわけのみこ）と表記。
sen.e: In the surviving fragment of 'Joguki' (Record of the Crown Prince), it is written as Homutawake no miko.
In the surviving fragment of 'Joguki' (Record of the Crown Prince), it is written as Homutawake no miko.

sen.j: 応神天皇の名とされる「ホムダワケ」（『日本書紀』では誉田別、『古事記』では品陀和気と表記）は、実は生前に使われた実名だった、とする説がある。
sen.e: There is a theory that 'Homudawake' (in "Nihonshoki" and "Kojiki," Chinese characters used are different) which is thought to be the posthumous name of Emperor Ojin was a real name used when he was alive.
sen.cmt: ①「ホムダワケ（ ）」の（ ）内は、読み方は一緒で、漢字が違うだけですので、「日本書紀と古事記で、使う漢字が違う」との注釈にしました。②「応神天皇の名とされる」の「名」は、「諡号」のことと解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: There is a theory that 'Homudawake' (in "Nihonshoki" and "Kojiki," Chinese characters used are different) which is thought to be the posthumous name of Emperor Ojin was a real name used when he was alive.

There is a theory that 'Homudawake' (in "Nihonshoki" and "Kojiki," Chinese characters used are different) which is thought to be the posthumous name of Emperor Ojin was a real name used when he was alive.

sen.j: 確実性を増してからの書紀の記述による限り、天皇に和風諡号を追号するようになったのは6世紀の半ば以降と見られる。
sen.e: According to descriptions of Nihonshoki after it increased certainty, it seems to be after the middle of the sixth century when it began to give a Japanese-style posthumous name to the Emperor.
According to descriptions of Nihonshoki after it increased certainty, it seems to be after the middle of the sixth century when it began to give a Japanese-style posthumous name to the Emperor.
According to descriptions of Nihonshoki after it increased certainty, it seems to be after the middle of the sixth century when it began to give a Japanese-style posthumous name to the Emperor.

sen.j: とくに応神天皇から継体天皇にかけての名は概して素朴であり、ワカタケルのように明らかに生前の実名と証明されたものもある。
sen.e: Especially, the posthumous names from Emperor Ojin through Emperor Keitai are generally simple and there are ones such as Wakatakeru, which were clearly proven to be the real names when alive.
sen.cmt: ここの「名」も「諡号」のことと解釈しました。
sen.e: Especially, the posthumous names from Emperor Ojin through Emperor Keitai are generally simple and there are ones such as Wakatakeru, which were clearly proven to be the real names when alive.
Especially, the posthumous names from Emperor Ojin through Emperor Keitai are generally simple and there are ones such as Wakatakeru, which were clearly proven to be the real names when alive.

sen.j: 22代清寧天皇のシラカタケヒロクニオシワカヤマトネコ（白髪武広国押稚日本根子、『日本書紀』に因る）のように明らかな和風諡号も見られるが、これはむしろ清寧天皇が後に皇統の列に加えられた架空の天皇である可能性を物語っている（ただし、清寧天皇の和風諡号は実名を基にした物であるため、実在した可能性が高い、とする説もある）。
sen.e: An obviously Japanese-style posthumous name can be seen as in Shiraka no takehirokunioshiwakayamatoneko no Sumeramikoto of the twenty-second Emperor Seinei (according to "Nihonshoki") but this rather suggests a possibility that Emperor Seinei is a fictional Emperor who was later included in the imperial line (however, there is a theory which proposes that there is a high possibility that Emperor Seinei actually existed because his Japanese-style posthumous name is based on a real name).

An obviously Japanese-style posthumous name can be seen as in Shiraka no takehirokunioshiwakayamatoneko no Sumeramikoto of the twenty-second Emperor Seinei (according to "Nihonshoki") but this rather suggests a possibility that Emperor Seinei is a fictional Emperor who was later included in the imperial line (however, there is a theory which proposes that there is a high possibility that Emperor Seinei actually existed because his Japanese-style posthumous name is based on a real name).

sen.j: 『日本書紀』には、吉備氏の祖として御友別（みともわけ）の名が、『古事記』には、近江国の安（やす）国造の祖先として意富多牟和気（おほたむわけ）の名が見えるが、これらの豪族の名の構成は「ホムダワケ」と全く同じである。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," there appears a name, Mitomowake as the ancestor of the Kibi clan and, in "Kojiki," there can be seen a name, Otamuwake as the ancestor of the Yasu no Kuni no miyatsuko (local ruling families in ancient Japan) in Omi Province, with constitution of the names of these local ruling families are exactly the same with 'Homudawake.'

In "Nihonshoki," there appears a name, Mitomowake as the ancestor of the Kibi clan and, in "Kojiki," there can be seen a name, Otamuwake as the ancestor of the Yasu no Kuni no miyatsuko (local ruling families in ancient Japan) in Omi Province, with constitution of the names of these local ruling families are exactly the same with 'Homudawake.'

In "Nihonshoki," there appears a name, Mitomowake as the ancestor of the Kibi clan and, in "Kojiki," there can be seen a name, Otamuwake as the ancestor of the Yasu no Kuni no miyatsuko (local ruling families in ancient Japan) in Omi Province, with constitution of the names of these local ruling families are exactly the same with 'Homudawake.'

sen.j: これらのことから、「ワケ」（別・和気・和希などと表記）の称を有する名は4世紀から5世紀にかけて皇族・地方豪族の区別なく存在し、ごく普遍的に用いられた名であることが分かる。
sen.e: From these considerations, names having the term 'wake' (written in several ways by Chinese characters) existed from fourth to fifth century irrespective of Imperial family or local ruling families, showing that this was a name used universally.
sen.cmt: ”「ワケ」（ ）”の（ ）内は、「ワケ」に対する漢字を説明していますので、注釈は「漢字では幾通りかの書き方がある」としました。
sen.e: From these considerations, names having the term 'wake' (written in several ways by Chinese characters) existed from fourth to fifth century irrespective of Imperial family or local ruling families, showing that this was a name used universally.

From these considerations, names having the term 'wake' (written in several ways by Chinese characters) existed from fourth to fifth century irrespective of Imperial family or local ruling families, showing that this was a name used universally.

sen.j: 事実、景行天皇・履中天皇・反正天皇の各天皇の名にも「ワケ」が含まれており、実名を基にした和風諡号である可能性が高い。
sen.e: As a matter of fact, the posthumous names for Emperors Keiko, Richu, and Hanzei include 'wake' and there is a high possibility that these are Japanese-style posthumous names based on real names.
As a matter of fact, the posthumous names for Emperors Keiko, Richu, and Hanzei include 'wake' and there is a high possibility that these are Japanese-style posthumous names based on real names.
As a matter of fact, the posthumous names for Emperors Keiko, Richu, and Hanzei include 'wake' and there is a high possibility that these are Japanese-style posthumous names based on real names.

sen.j: 以上の点から、応神天皇の「ホムダワケ」と言う名も実名だった、とこの仮説では見なしている。
sen.e: From these points, the above hypothesis assumes that 'Homudawake' of Emperor Ojin was also a real name.
From these points, the above hypothesis assumes that 'Homudawake' of Emperor Ojin was also a real name.

sen.j: なお、この「ワケ」の語義ならびに由来については、諸説あって明らかにしがたい。
sen.e: In addition, as to the meaning and origin of this 'wake,' there are too many theories to be clarified.
In addition, as to the meaning and origin of this 'wake,' there are too many theories to be clarified.

sen.j: 『古事記』では、景行天皇が設置した地方官の官職名であり、皇族から分かれて諸地方に分封された豪族の称としている。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," it is a name of a government post of a local official which Emperor Keiko established and is a title for local ruling families who separated from the Imperial family and were given lands in various regions.
sen.cmt: 「分封された」は「土地を与えられた」と同義よ解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," it is a name of a government post of a local official which Emperor Keiko established and is a title for local ruling families who separated from the Imperial family and were given lands in various regions.

sen.j: が、これは観念的説明であろう。
sen.e: However, this may be an ideological explanation.
However, this may be an ideological explanation.

sen.j: 父は先帝仲哀天皇で、母は神功皇后こと息長足姫尊（おきながたらしひめのみこと）とされるが、異説も多い。
sen.e: It is said that his father was Ex-Emperor Chuai and his mother was Empress Jingu, namely Okinagatarashihime no mikoto, but there are many different opinions.

sen.j: その理由は異常に出産が遅れたことにある。
sen.e: The reason is that his birth was delayed abnormally.

sen.j: 父として「是に皇后、大神と密事あり」（住吉大社の住吉大社神代記」）とある住吉大神や、あるいはまた武内宿禰とする考えもある。
sen.e: There is a view that his father was Sumiyoshi Okami or Takeuchi no Sukune, there being with the former a description that 'the Empress had a secret relationship with Okami' (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine).

sen.j: このような出生の神秘性は、本来応神天皇が前王朝との血統上のつながりを持たず、新王朝の開祖であるとされたことを物語っているとするものもある。
sen.e: Some people argue that this mysteriousness of his birth suggests that Emperor Ojin fundamentally had no blood line connection to the previous dynasty and was regarded as the founder of a new dynasty.

sen.j: 都は軽島豊明宮（かるしまのとよあきらのみや、現在の奈良県橿原市大軽町か）。
sen.e: The capital was Karushima no toyoakira no miya (probably, present-day Okaru Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 古事記には、軽島之明宮と見える。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、大阪にも大隅宮（おおすみのみや。現在の大阪市東淀川区大隅、一説に同市中央区 (大阪市)）が置かれたという。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," there was also built, in Osaka, Osumi no miya (present-day Osumi, Higashi Yodogawa Ward, Osaka City, or, according to one theory, Chuo Ward of Osaka City).

sen.j: 神功皇后の三韓征伐の帰途に宇瀰（うみ、福岡県糟屋郡宇美町）で生まれたとされる。
sen.e: On her way back from sankan-seibatsu (the conquest of three countries in old Korea), Empress Jingu gave birth to him at Umi (Umi Town, Kasuya County, Fukuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 神功4年（204年）に立太子。
sen.e: In 204, there was an investiture of the Crown Prince.

sen.j: 応神天皇元年（270年）に71歳で即位、同41年（310年）に111歳で崩御。
sen.e: In 270, he acceded to the throne at the age of 71 and passed away in 310 at the age of 111.
In 270, he acceded to the throne at the age of 71 and passed away in 310 at the age of 111.
In 270, he acceded to the throne at the age of 71 and passed away in 310 at the age of 111.

sen.j: 『古事記』に130歳。
sen.e: "Kojiki" has it that he passed away at the age of 130.
"Kojiki" has it that he passed away at the age of 130.
"Kojiki" has it that he passed away at the age of 130.

sen.j: 『古事記』に「この御世に、海部（あまべ）、山部、山守部、伊勢部を定めたまひき。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," in his reign, he established Amabe, Yamabe, Yama no moribe, and Isebe (groups of people related respectively to sea products, mountains, mountain management, and Ise Province.
sen.cmt: 「海部、山部、山守部、伊勢部」はそれぞれ「海産物、山、山の管理、伊勢」の関連する人の集団」と解釈して注釈を入れました。参考：http://members.at.infoseek.co.jp/accord/BIGLOBE/BUKKYOU/nip04970.htm
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," in his reign, he established Amabe, Yamabe, Yama no moribe, and Isebe (groups of people related respectively to sea products, mountains, mountain management, and Ise Province.
According to "Kojiki," in his reign, he established Amabe, Yamabe, Yama no moribe, and Isebe (groups of people related respectively to sea products, mountains, mountain management, and Ise Province.

sen.j: また、剣池（つるぎのいけ）を作りき。
sen.e: He had Tsurugi no ike-Pond built.
He had Tsurugi no ike-Pond built.
He had Tsurugi no ike-Pond built.

sen.j: また新羅人参渡（まいわた）り来つ。
sen.e: Also, people of Silla came over.
Also, people of Silla came over.
Also, people of Silla came over.

sen.j: ここをもちて武内宿禰引い率て、堤池に役ちて、百済池（くだらのいけ）を作りき」。
sen.e: For this reason, he let Takeucho no Sukune lead the people and go to Tsutsumiike to build Kudara (Paekche) no ike-Pond.
sen.cmt: ①「ここをもちて」は「こういう訳で」または「それ故に」と解釈しました。参考（ウェブ）：kotobank.jp/word ②「読み方不明」：「堤池」は単純に「Tsutsumiike」としました。
sen.e: For this reason, he let Takeucho no Sukune lead the people and go to Tsutsumiike to build Kudara (Paekche) no ike-Pond.
For this reason, he let Takeucho no Sukune lead the people and go to Tsutsumiike to build Kudara (Paekche) no ike-Pond.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』にも同様の記事が見え、応神五年八月条に「諸国に令して、海人及び山守を定む」、応神十一年十月条に「剣池・軽池（かるのいけ）・鹿垣池（ししかきのいけ）・厩坂池（うまやさかのいけ）を作る」とある。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" also, a similar story appears and the paragraph titled September, 274 says that 'he sent an order to all countries and determined diver groups and mountain guardian groups' and the paragraph titled November, 280 says that 'he had Tsurugi no ike-Pond, Karu no ike-Pond, Shishikaki no ike-Pond, and Umaya no saka no ike-Pond built.'

In "Nihonshoki" also, a similar story appears and the paragraph titled September, 274 says that 'he sent an order to all countries and determined diver groups and mountain guardian groups' and the paragraph titled November, 280 says that 'he had Tsurugi no ike-Pond, Karu no ike-Pond, Shishikaki no ike-Pond, and Umaya no saka no ike-Pond built.'

In "Nihonshoki" also, a similar story appears and the paragraph titled September, 274 says that 'he sent an order to all countries and determined diver groups and mountain guardian groups' and the paragraph titled November, 280 says that 'he had Tsurugi no ike-Pond, Karu no ike-Pond, Shishikaki no ike-Pond, and Umaya no saka no ike-Pond built.'

sen.j: 剣池は奈良県橿原市石川町の石川池という。
sen.e: The Tsurugi no ike-Pond is said to be the Ishikawaike-Pond in Ishikawa Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
The Tsurugi no ike-Pond is said to be the Ishikawaike-Pond in Ishikawa Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
The Tsurugi no ike-Pond is said to be the Ishikawaike-Pond in Ishikawa Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 『古事記』に、百済の国主照古王（百済の近肖古王）が、雄雌各一頭を阿知吉師（あちきし）に付けて献上したとある。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," it is described that King Shoko of Kudara (Paekche, King Geunchogo) presented horses, one male and one female, which accompanied Achikishi.
sen.cmt: 何の雄、雌か分からないので、ウェブ検索から「馬」としました。参考：http//j-myth.info/nihongi2/nihongi10.html
sen.e: In "Kojiki," it is described that King Shoko of Kudara (Paekche, King Geunchogo) presented horses, one male and one female, which accompanied Achikishi.
In "Kojiki," it is described that King Shoko of Kudara (Paekche, King Geunchogo) presented horses, one male and one female, which accompanied Achikishi.

sen.j: この阿知吉師は阿直史等の祖。
sen.e: This Achikishi was the founder of Achiki no fubito.
sen.cmt: 「読み方不明」：「阿直史等」はウェブから、「あちきのふびと」と読みました。参考：http//j-myth.info/nihongi2/nihongi10.html
sen.e: This Achikishi was the founder of Achiki no fubito.
This Achikishi was the founder of Achiki no fubito.

sen.j: また、横刀（たち）や大鏡を献上した。
sen.e: The King also presented a sword and a large mirror.
The King also presented a sword and a large mirror.
The King also presented a sword and a large mirror.

sen.j: また「もし賢人しき人あらば貢上れ」と仰せになったので、「命を受けて貢上れる人、名は王仁（わにきし）。すなわち論語十巻、千字文一巻、併せて十一巻をこの人に付けてすなわち貢進りき。この和爾吉師は文首等の祖。また手人韓鍛（てひとからかぬち）名は卓素（たくそ）また呉服（くれはとり）の西素（さいそ）二人を貢上りき」。
sen.e: Further, because the Emperor asked 'if there were a wise man, bring him as a tribute, 'in response to his order, sent as a tribute was Wanikishi. Accompanying this man, there were presented 10 volumes of Rongo Analects and 1 volume of Senjimon, total 11 volumes. This Wanikishi was the ancestor of Humi no obito, etc. Also sent as tributes were two people, a blacksmith named Takuso and a weaver, Saiso.'
sen.cmt: ①「賢人しき」は「かしこき」と読むと解釈しました。②ウェブから、「手人韓鍛」は「鍛冶屋」、「呉服」は「機織り」を指すものと解釈して訳しました (http//suzumoto.s217.xrea.com/2009/02/korea20090220_2html)。③「読み方不明」：「文首」は「ふみのおびと」と読みました。参考：inoues.net/Tenno/oujin.html
sen.e: Further, because the Emperor asked 'if there were a wise man, bring him as a tribute, 'in response to his order, sent as a tribute was Wanikishi. Accompanying this man, there were presented 10 volumes of Rongo Analects and 1 volume of Senjimon, total 11 volumes. This Wanikishi was the ancestor of Humi no obito, etc. Also sent as tributes were two people, a blacksmith named Takuso and a weaver, Saiso.'

Further, because the Emperor asked 'if there were a wise man, bring him as a tribute, 'in response to his order, sent as a tribute was Wanikishi. Accompanying this man, there were presented 10 volumes of Rongo Analects and 1 volume of Senjimon, total 11 volumes. This Wanikishi was the ancestor of Humi no obito, etc. Also sent as tributes were two people, a blacksmith named Takuso and a weaver, Saiso.'

sen.j: 『書紀』の十五年八月条と十六年二月条に同様の記事が見える。
sen.e: There are similar stories in the paragraphs titled August, 284 and March, 285 of "Nihonshoki."
There are similar stories in the paragraphs titled August, 284 and March, 285 of "Nihonshoki."
There are similar stories in the paragraphs titled August, 284 and March, 285 of "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: また、応神二十年九月条に「倭の漢直の祖阿知使主（あちのおみ）、其の子都加使主、並びに己が党類十七県を率て、来帰り」とあって、多くの渡来人があったことを伝えている。
sen.e: Furthermore, the paragraph titled October, 289 describes that 'Achi no omi, the ancester of Yamato no aya no atai, his son Tsuka no omi, and his relatives from seventeen provinces came over,' suggesting that there were many settlers.

Furthermore, the paragraph titled October, 289 describes that 'Achi no omi, the ancester of Yamato no aya no atai, his son Tsuka no omi, and his relatives from seventeen provinces came over,' suggesting that there were many settlers.

Furthermore, the paragraph titled October, 289 describes that 'Achi no omi, the ancester of Yamato no aya no atai, his son Tsuka no omi, and his relatives from seventeen provinces came over,' suggesting that there were many settlers.

sen.j: 後世、神功皇后と共に八幡神に付会され、皇祖神や武神として各地の八幡宮に祭られる。
sen.e: In later years, together with Empress Jingu, he was related to Hachimanshin (God of War) and was enshrined as Imperial ancestor and bushin in Hachiman-gu Shrines in various places.
In later years, together with Empress Jingu, he was related to Hachimanshin (God of War) and was enshrined as Imperial ancestor and bushin in Hachiman-gu Shrines in various places.
In later years, together with Empress Jingu, he was related to Hachimanshin (God of War) and was enshrined as Imperial ancestor and bushin in Hachiman-gu Shrines in various places.

sen.j: 『古事記』に「御陵は河内国の恵賀（えが）の裳伏（もふし）岡にあり」と記す。
sen.e: "Kojiki" describes that 'Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) is located on Mofushi Hill in Ega, Kawachi Province.'
"Kojiki" describes that 'Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) is located on Mofushi Hill in Ega, Kawachi Province.'
"Kojiki" describes that 'Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) is located on Mofushi Hill in Ega, Kawachi Province.'

sen.j: 『書紀』に陵名の記載はないが、雄略紀に「蓬丘（いちびこのおか）の誉田陵」と見える。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," there is no description of the name of the mausoleum but in Yuryakuki (a volume on Emperor Yuryaku), there appears 'Konda Mausoleum on Ichibiko no oka (hill).'
sen.cmt: 「誉田陵」の読みは、２節後の「誉田山古墳」に合わせ、「こんだりょう」としました。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," there is no description of the name of the mausoleum but in Yuryakuki (a volume on Emperor Yuryaku), there appears 'Konda Mausoleum on Ichibiko no oka (hill).'
In "Nihonshoki," there is no description of the name of the mausoleum but in Yuryakuki (a volume on Emperor Yuryaku), there appears 'Konda Mausoleum on Ichibiko no oka (hill).'

sen.j: 『延喜式』諸陵寮に恵我藻伏崗陵（えがのもふしのおかのみささぎ）。
sen.e: In the paragraph on Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) in "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), there appears Ega no Mofushi no oka Mausoleum.

In the paragraph on Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) in "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), there appears Ega no Mofushi no oka Mausoleum.

In the paragraph on Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums) in "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), there appears Ega no Mofushi no oka Mausoleum.

sen.j: 現在、同陵は大阪府羽曳野市誉田六丁目の誉田山古墳（前方後円墳・全長425m・後円部高さ36m、もと二重に堀をめぐらしていた）に比定される。
sen.e: At present, the mausoleum is identified with Konda gobyoyama tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus, 425 m in total length and 36 m in height of the rounded part, originally surrounded by double moats).

At present, the mausoleum is identified with Konda gobyoyama tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus, 425 m in total length and 36 m in height of the rounded part, originally surrounded by double moats).

At present, the mausoleum is identified with Konda gobyoyama tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus, 425 m in total length and 36 m in height of the rounded part, originally surrounded by double moats).

sen.j: 大仙陵古墳（仁徳天皇陵）につぐ（第2位の規模）5世紀初ともいわれる大前方後円墳。
sen.e: It is a large keyhole-shaped tumulus built in early fifth century, next (second in size) to the Daisenryo Tumulus (Mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku),
It is a large keyhole-shaped tumulus built in early fifth century, next (second in size) to the Daisenryo Tumulus (Mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku),
It is a large keyhole-shaped tumulus built in early fifth century, next (second in size) to the Daisenryo Tumulus (Mausoleum of Emperor Nintoku),

sen.j: ただし考古学の絶対年代はよほど強力な史料などが出ない限り、常に浮動的であることに注意する必要がある。
sen.e: However, it is to be noted that a conclusive age in archeology is always floating unless there appears an exceptionally strong historical material, etc.
However, it is to be noted that a conclusive age in archeology is always floating unless there appears an exceptionally strong historical material, etc.
However, it is to be noted that a conclusive age in archeology is always floating unless there appears an exceptionally strong historical material, etc.
